active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs between stealth (e.g., DNS tunneling) and speed (e.g., cloud services like Dropbox) in data exfiltration patterns. How do these impact dwell time, and what behavioral IoCs would you prioritize for hunting?
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

layer.name: Layer 1
layer.content: Define key terms: Data Exfiltration (unauthorized data theft from systems/networks); C2 Channel (adversary communication link); Covert Channels (hidden data paths in legit protocols); Dwell Time (compromise-to-detection period); Behavioral IoCs (patterns like anomalous outbound traffic). Sources: offensivebytes.com/data-exfiltration-in-modern-environments, attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1048, hunt.io/glossary/threat-hunting-process.

layer.name: Layer 2
layer.content: Core patterns: 1. Network Protocol Abuse - DNS Tunneling (data in TXT/subdomains), ICMP Tunneling (payloads in echo requests), HTTP/HTTPS (steganography/large POSTs), SMB/RDP/File Transfer (unexpected shares/sessions), FTP/SFTP (direct transfers); 2. C2 Channels (T1041: over Beacon/DNS C2); 3. Cloud Services (T1567: Dropbox/OneDrive uploads); 4. Email (T1567.002: attachments); 5. Physical Media (T1011: USB exfil). Relationships: Often combined with encryption; tied to dwell time extension.

layer.name: Layer 3
layer.content: Practical steps: 1. Monitor anomalies (e.g., DNS query volume > threshold, SMB to internet); 2. Hunt queries (e.g., Zeek logs for large HTTP POSTs); 3. Behavioral rules (Sigma: high entropy DNS, unusual RDP); 4. Tools (Wireshark for PCAPs, Splunk/ELK for logs). MITRE mappings: TA0010 techniques.

layer.name: Layer 4
layer.content: Link to Threat Hunting: Reduce dwell time via proactive IoC hunting; Integrate with full ATT&CK (e.g., post-exploitation TA0002); Scenario: APT using DNS C2 + cloud exfil; Advanced: ML for anomaly detection in patterns.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Threat Intelligence. Topic: Data Exfiltration Patterns (Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Threat Intelligence And Hunting > Threat Intelligence Types > 006_Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) > Behavioral IoCs > Data Exfiltration Patterns). Use the provided learning_objectives, active_learning, scaffolding (including prior_knowledge_connections and concept_map), and flashcard_schema to generate high-quality flashcards. Incorporate: Voter consensus (82.9% approval); Complete patterns (DNS Tunneling, ICMP, HTTP, SMB/RDP/FTP, C2, Cloud (Dropbox/OneDrive), Email, Physical Media); Sources (offensivebytes.com, attack.mitre.org/TA0010, hunt.io). Ensure university pedagogy: Bloom's progression, active recall, spaced repetition-friendly. Output ONLY a JSON array of 25-30 flashcards, each strictly matching the flashcard_schema (question, correct_answer, distractors [exactly 3 strings], explanation, bloom_level, scaffolding_layer). Cover all objectives/layers evenly. Questions must be precise, distractors plausible/misconception-based, explanations pedagogical with MITRE links.
